data.title: Relocating the "local coords" option
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):**
Godot 3.0

**Issue description:**
I think the "local coords" option should be more accessible than hiding it in the transform menu, I think it should be enable by just one click, thus, the option should be locate somewhere in the viewport.

Now:
![2017-10-04 21 30 37](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10883749/31178679-63a46856-a94c-11e7-8f09-9bca001958af.png)

Idea:
![2017-10-04 21 30](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10883749/31178707-7552a518-a94c-11e7-9b76-b868c515a14e.png)
The gizmos in the corner may not be necessary, that's just a idea where the "local coords" option should be.
Another idea would be placing the checkbox next to the "view"

data.title: Multiple locks on web thread not allowed! Please file a bug. Crashing now
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):**
2.1
iOS

**Issue description:**
When load a banner and a interstitial, then show the banner and interstitial, all the methods are called on the main thread, the app will crash when close the interstitial.
However, if I only load  and show a interstitial, it will work without any problem.
<!-- What happened, and what was expected. -->
2017-10-04 20:52:56.354364+0800 godot_opt.iphone[8656:3238154] bool _WebTryThreadLock(bool), 0x1c401fc10: Multiple locks on web thread not allowed! Please file a bug. Crashing now...

**Steps to reproduce:**


**Link to minimal example project:**
<!-- Optional but very welcome. You can drag and drop a zip archive to upload it. -->

data.title: Fix type error in subsurface scattering shader code
data.body:
I was reading sss shader and it seems there's a type error in the shader, which will lead to crash with the log like below:

```
1: #version 330
2: #define GLES_OVER_GL
3: #define USE_11_SAMPLES
4: #define ENABLE_STRENGTH_WEIGHTING
5: precision highp float;
6: precision highp int;
7:
8: //#define QUALIFIER uniform // some guy on the interweb says it may be faster with this
9: #define QUALIFIER const
10:
11: #ifdef USE_25_SAMPLES
12:
13: const int kernel_size=25;
14: QUALIFIER vec2 kernel[25] = vec2[] (
15:     vec2(0.530605, 0.0),
16:     vec2(0.000973794, -3.0),
17:     vec2(0.00333804, -2.52083),
18:     vec2(0.00500364, -2.08333),
19:     vec2(0.00700976,  -1.6875),
20:     vec2(0.0094389, -1.33333),
21:     vec2(0.0128496,  -1.02083),
22:     vec2(0.017924,  -0.75),
23:     vec2(0.0263642,  -0.520833),
24:     vec2(0.0410172, -0.333333),
25:     vec2(0.0493588, -0.1875),
26:     vec2(0.0402784, -0.0833333),
27:     vec2(0.0211412,  -0.0208333),
28:     vec2(0.0211412,  0.0208333),
29:     vec2(0.0402784,  0.0833333),
30:     vec2(0.0493588,  0.1875),
31:     vec2(0.0410172,  0.333333),
32:     vec2(0.0263642,  0.520833),
33:     vec2(0.017924,  0.75),
34:     vec2(0.0128496, 1.02083),
35:     vec2(0.0094389,  1.33333),
36:     vec2(0.00700976,  1.6875),
37:     vec2(0.00500364,  2.08333),
38:     vec2(0.00333804,  2.52083),
39:     vec2(0.000973794,  3.0)
40: );
41:
42: #endif //USE_25_SAMPLES
43:
44: #ifdef USE_17_SAMPLES
45:
46: const int kernel_size=17;
47:
48: QUALIFIER vec2 kernel[17] = vec2[](
49:     vec2(0.536343,  0.0),
50:     vec2(0.00317394,  -2.0),
51:     vec2(0.0100386, -1.53125),
52:     vec2(0.0144609, -1.125),
53:     vec2(0.0216301,  -0.78125),
54:     vec2(0.0347317, -0.5),
55:     vec2(0.0571056,  -0.28125),
56:     vec2(0.0582416,  -0.125),
57:     vec2(0.0324462, -0.03125),
58:     vec2(0.0324462, 0.03125),
59:     vec2(0.0582416, 0.125),
60:     vec2(0.0571056,  0.28125),
61:     vec2(0.0347317, 0.5),
62:     vec2(0.0216301, 0.78125),
63:     vec2(0.0144609,  1.125),
64:     vec2(0.0100386,  1.53125),
65:     vec2(0.00317394,2.0)
66: );
67:
68: #endif //USE_17_SAMPLES
69:
70:
71: #ifdef USE_11_SAMPLES
72:
73: const int kernel_size=11;
74:
75: QUALIFIER vec4 kernel[11] = vec4[](
76:     vec4(0.560479,  0.0),
77:     vec4(0.00471691,  -2.0),
78:     vec4(0.0192831, -1.28),
79:     vec4(0.03639, -0.72),
80:     vec4(0.0821904,  -0.32),
81:     vec4(0.0771802, -0.08),
82:     vec4(0.0771802,  0.08),
83:     vec4(0.0821904, 0.32),
84:     vec4(0.03639, 0.72),
85:     vec4(0.0192831, 1.28),
86:     vec4(0.00471691,2.0)
87: );
88:
89: #endif //USE_11_SAMPLES
90:
91:
92:
93: uniform float max_radius;
94: uniform float camera_z_far;
95: uniform float camera_z_near;
96: uniform float unit_size;
97: uniform vec2 dir;
98: in vec2 uv_interp;
99:
100: uniform sampler2D source_diffuse; //texunit:0
101: uniform sampler2D source_sss; //texunit:1
102: uniform sampler2D source_depth; //texunit:2
103:
104: layout(location = 0) out vec4 frag_color;
105:
106: void main() {
107:
108:    float strength = texture(source_sss,uv_interp).r;
109:    strength*=strength; //stored as sqrt
110:
111:    // Fetch color of current pixel:
112:    vec4 base_color = texture(source_diffuse, uv_interp);
113:
114:
115:    if (strength>0.0) {
116:
117:
118:            // Fetch linear depth of current pixel:
119:            float depth = texture(source_depth, uv_interp).r * 2.0 - 1.0;
120: #ifdef USE_ORTHOGONAL_PROJECTION
121:            depth = ((depth + (camera_z_far + camera_z_near)/(camera_z_far - camera_z_near)) * (camera_z_far - camera_z_near))/2.0;
122:            float scale = unit_size; //remember depth is negative by default in OpenGL
123: #else
124:            depth = 2.0 * camera_z_near * camera_z_far / (camera_z_far + camera_z_near - depth * (camera_z_far - camera_z_near));
125:            float scale = unit_size / depth; //remember depth is negative by default in OpenGL
126: #endif
127:
128:
129:
130:            // Calculate the final step to fetch the surrounding pixels:
131:            vec2 step = max_radius * scale * dir;
132:            step *= strength; // Modulate it using the alpha channel.
133:            step *= 1.0 / 3.0; // Divide by 3 as the kernels range from -3 to 3.
134:
135:            // Accumulate the center sample:
136:            vec3 color_accum = base_color.rgb;
137:            color_accum *= kernel[0].x;
138: #ifdef ENABLE_STRENGTH_WEIGHTING
139:            float color_weight = kernel[0].x;
140: #endif
141:
142:            // Accumulate the other samples:
143:            for (int i = 1; i < kernel_size; i++) {
144:                    // Fetch color and depth for current sample:
145:                    vec2 offset = uv_interp + kernel[i].y * step;
146:                    vec3 color = texture(source_diffuse, offset).rgb;
147:
148: #ifdef ENABLE_FOLLOW_SURFACE
149:                    // If the difference in depth is huge, we lerp color back to "colorM":
150:                    float depth_cmp = texture(source_depth, offset).r *2.0 - 1.0;
151:
152: #ifdef USE_ORTHOGONAL_PROJECTION
153:                    depth_cmp = ((depth_cmp + (camera_z_far + camera_z_near)/(camera_z_far - camera_z_near)) * (camera_z_far - camera_z_near))/2.0;
154: #else
155:                    depth_cmp = 2.0 * camera_z_near * camera_z_far / (camera_z_far + camera_z_near - depth_cmp * (camera_z_far - camera_z_near));
156: #endif
157:
158:                    float s = clamp(300.0f * scale *
159:                                           max_radius * abs(depth - depth_cmp),0.0,1.0);
160:                    color = mix(color, base_color.rgb, s);
161: #endif
162:
163:                    // Accumulate:
164:                    color*=kernel[i].x;
165:
166: #ifdef ENABLE_STRENGTH_WEIGHTING
167:                    float color_s = texture(source_sss, offset).r;
168:                    color_weight+=color_s * kernel[i].x;
169:                    color*=color_s;
170: #endif
171:                    color_accum += color;
172:
173:            }
174:
175: #ifdef ENABLE_STRENGTH_WEIGHTING
176:            color_accum/=color_weight;
177: #endif
178:            frag_color = vec4(color_accum,base_color.a); //keep alpha (used for SSAO)
179:    } else {
180:            frag_color = base_color;
181:    }
182: }
183:
184:
ERROR: _display_error_with_code: SubsurfScatteringShaderGLES3: Fragment Program Compilation Failed:
0:76(2): error: too few components to construct `vec4'
0:77(2): error: too few components to construct `vec4'
0:78(2): error: too few components to construct `vec4'
0:79(2): error: too few components to construct `vec4'
0:80(2): error: too few components to construct `vec4'
0:81(2): error: too few components to construct `vec4'
0:82(2): error: too few components to construct `vec4'
0:83(2): error: too few components to construct `vec4'
0:84(2): error: too few components to construct `vec4'
0:85(2): error: too few components to construct `vec4'
0:86(2): error: too few components to construct `vec4'
0:75(25): error: type error in array constructor: expected: vec4, found error
0:75(25): error: initializer of const variable `kernel' must be a constant expression

   At: drivers/gles3/shader_gles3.cpp:167.
handle_crash: Program crashed with signal 11
Dumping the backtrace. Please include this when reporting the bug on https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues
[1] /usr/lib/libc.so.6(+0x34920) [0x7f7d1bb4a920] (??:0)
[2] /usr/lib/libc.so.6(+0x157247) [0x7f7d1bc6d247] (??:0)
[3] /usr/lib/libc.so.6(_IO_vfprintf+0x201d) [0x7f7d1bb64e4d] (??:0)
[4] /usr/lib/libc.so.6(vsnprintf+0x92) [0x7f7d1bb8c712] (??:0)
[5] RotatedFileLogger::logv(char const*, __va_list_tag*, bool) (??:0)
[6] Logger::logf_error(char const*, ...) (??:0)
[7] Logger::log_error(char const*, char const*, int, char const*, char const*, Logger::ErrorType) (??:0)
[8] CompositeLogger::log_error(char const*, char const*, int, char const*, char const*, Logger::ErrorType) (??:0)
[9] OS::print_error(char const*, char const*, int, char const*, char const*, Logger::ErrorType) (??:0)
[10] _err_print_error(char const*, char const*, int, char const*, ErrorHandlerType) (??:0)
[11] ./bin/godot.x11.tools.64.llvm(+0x2894e4f) [0x55aa0ebc5e4f] (??:0)
[12] ShaderGLES3::get_current_version() (??:0)
[13] ShaderGLES3::bind() (??:0)
[14] RasterizerSceneGLES3::_render_mrts(RasterizerSceneGLES3::Environment*, CameraMatrix const&) (??:0)
[15] RasterizerSceneGLES3::render_scene(Transform const&, CameraMatrix const&, bool, RasterizerScene::InstanceBase**, int, RID*, int, RID*, int, RID, RID, RID, RID, int) (??:0)
[16] VisualServerScene::_render_scene(Transform, CameraMatrix const&, bool, RID, unsigned int, RID, RID, RID, int) (??:0)
[17] VisualServerScene::render_camera(RID, RID, Vector2, RID) (??:0)
[18] VisualServerViewport::_draw_viewport(VisualServerViewport::Viewport*, ARVRInterface::Eyes) (??:0)
[19] VisualServerViewport::draw_viewports() (??:0)
[20] VisualServerRaster::draw() (??:0)
[21] VisualServerWrapMT::draw() (??:0)
[22] Main::iteration() (??:0)
[23] OS_X11::run() (??:0)
[24] ./bin/godot.x11.tools.64.llvm(main+0x15e) [0x55aa0e45326e] (??:0)
[25] /usr/lib/libc.so.6(__libc_start_main+0xea) [0x7f7d1bb36f6a] (??:0)
[26] ./bin/godot.x11.tools.64.llvm(_start+0x2a) [0x55aa0e45302a] (??:0)
-- END OF BACKTRACE --
Aborted (core dumped)
```

These lines are covered with macro so it only happens conditionally, which is when sss's quality (or project setting "rendering/quality/subsurface_scattering/weight_samples") is chosen to be low.

This PR will fix that.

data.title: Fix returning Game Center player ID
Fix GIProbe light visibility
data.body:
Hi godot team.
I've been looking around engine code base and I found that this issue https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/10535 might be something I could fix.

I tested the example scene from the original issue.

Here is two screenshots before and after this change. Note that "red omni1" is set to invisible.

_BEFORE_

![giprobe-fix-before](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4232207/31168687-2aad0e6a-a931-11e7-81c6-090e61c725ca.png)


_AFTER_

![giprobe-fix-after](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4232207/31168706-3a080c3e-a931-11e7-8d24-2b089dca6616.png)


Since I just stared learning game system and computer graphics based on godot engine, I might be missing something obvious here in my change, so any correction or advice will be appreciated. Thanks!

data.title: Fix logging on iOS
data.body:
RotatedFileLogger needs data_dir on iOS to be initialized, so setting
data_dir has been moved to initialize_core.

data.title: Allow to obtain virtual keyboard height
data.body:
On mobile platforms virtual keyboards take up significant amount of
screen space and UI containing a text box may need to be adjusted
after the keyboard appears to keep the text box visible to user. This
commit adds a way to obtain virtual keyabord height so that controls
are aware of how much they need to move.

data.title: Shader blend mode MUL and MIX is equals
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):**
Godot 3.0 master build b2046836401fe5cdaf4ae6ae32ad3323511b956d

**Issue description:**
In spatial shader material `blend_mix` and `blend_mul` produce the same result.

According the implementation https://github.com/godotengine/godot/blob/master/drivers/gles3/rasterizer_scene_gles3.cpp#L2061 it contains identically code.

data.title: Replaces (and extends) the anchor menu to a Layout one
data.body:
The presets menus changes both anchors and margins. But it has also two submenus for moving either "Anchors only" or "Margins only"

Not the best gif ever but you can see the changes:
![output](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6093119/31164274-bb1da0cc-a8e6-11e7-95ce-cfba2e6d2a21.gif)

Closes #11723.

data.title: [DOCS] Update ParticlesMaterial, Particles, Particles2D class ref
data.body: ParticlesMaterial was a big one. I'm still not entirely clear on the usage of EMISSION_SHAPE_POINTS and EMISSION_SHAPE_DIRECTED_POINTS, so I left those blank for now.

The "range" variable seems present, I don't see why "aperture" shouldn't be as well.

data.title: Add function set_stream_position to VideoPlayer. Closes #8727
data.body:
Hey, it's my first contribution to Godot ! I was looking around for small things to implement to get started and found this feature proposal #8727 

I haven't being able to test it yet due to this issue #10031 though :/

data.title: [GDNative] added API struct wrapper generator
data.body:
Previously functions of the GDNative API were accessed by letting
the loader at load-time resolve the symbols. This causes troubles on
Windows (...sigh...), so now the GDNative API isn't exported anymore.

This means, that a library that wants to call a GDNative function
needs to access it via a struct of pointers that's passed to it at
right after the library was loaded. To make the usage easier, those
function pointers in the struct can be wrapped in actual function in
the global scope. This commit adds a generator for that wrapper code.

data.title: Fixes the Control pre-drag rect not drawn correctly
data.body: Fixes #11671

data.title: Self contained mode doesn't work perfectly
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):**
Tested it under Linux, with latest build from master

**Issue description:**
<!-- What happened, and what was expected. -->
**UPDATE: The self contained mode works as expected, the problem was located inside the mono module. So no need to read the wall of text anymore :)** 

So the "self contained mode" is a mode to start Godot without touching the system wide configuration of a previous started Godot session. It's very useful if you test different versions of Godot on your system and want to avoid to interfere with other versions. 
Here the description from the docs:  
http://docs.godotengine.org/en/latest/development/compiling/packaging_godot.html?highlight=self-contained#self-contained-mode

Now I already had the impression that it didn't work perfectly in Godot 3.0, but to really be sure about it I removed all files (also the invisible ones) from both the system wide path where Godot per default saves its configuration(s) and the one in my folder from where I test Godot with the self contained mode.
Here the before picture:  
![issue_self-contained-mode_before](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16520617/31145393-f04fd2d2-a883-11e7-8f88-889c9b414911.png)

As you can see, everything is deleted in this picture.  
Now to clarify: The folder on the top is the one where Godot saves its default configuration(s), so in this case under Linux it's **"~/.godot/"**. While at the bottom you find two views from the same empty folder where I test Godot starting in self contained mode. Before I started I did as usual, so copied the clean built binaries, in this case godot.x11.opt.tools.64, godot.x11.opt.tools.64.debug and GodotSharpTools.dll (because testing the newly added Mono support and to prove the point) and created a new empty "._sc_" file like I always do since Godot 2.x.  Now when starting Godot in this mode normally it should create a **"editor_data"** folder in which it will then put all the configuration stuff (and also templates etc. if you import any). The problem is not that it doesn't work, indeed it works, but just not perfectly. As you can see as soon as I started it, it also created two folders in the system wide Godot configuration folder (which should not happen in this mode):  
![issue_self-contained-mode_after](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16520617/31145915-522bf552-a885-11e7-9119-63de026ee5b3.png)  

Now it created the two folders: "app_userdata" and "mono". In case of app_userdata, it held a folder inside of a game project that I quickly created to test (you can see at the bottom that I also created a "GameProjects" folder in which it has been saved. Now that "Test_Game" folder inside "app_userdata" was empty. But in case of "mono" it wasn't indeed it held the folders for mono's building logs and two folder for the solution files of GodotSharp and GodotSharpEditor. Now most of the stuff got into "editor_data" but the mono folder didn't. Talking with @neikeq he said it could be an issue with the "**get_settings_path()**" function in "**EditorSettings**", as it should return exe_path + "editor_data" for the self-contained mode. On a second note other folders are as expected within the "editor_data" folder in the self contained folder.


**Steps to reproduce:**

1. Delete all the content in the default configuration folder of Godot (~/.godot/ or equivalent for Windows and OS X)  

2. choose a empty folder where you want to test Godot in self contained mode and create a empty file called "**._sc_**" in it. 

3. make a clean build of Godot with the targets set as you please (but consider trying it with module_mono_enabled=yes so you can test the behavior)

4. copy the binarie(s) to the folder where you have created the "**._sc_**" file and execute Godot. Maybe create also a simple project (1 node is enough and save the scene), so you can also see that it still creates the "**app_userdata**" (and the mono folder) where Godot would per default save them when **not** run in self contained mode.

data.title: Fixed a bug where ssl would force validation even though you told it not to.
Visual script Array front() back() don't have output node
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):**
OSX 10.12.5
Godot 3 built at commit 49afad2b4

**Issue description:**
In Visual Script editor
Array `front()` `back()` don't have output data port.
In `Select Method` these functions are noted return `void` (though as I check in the source code, they return `Variant`?)

Expected behavior:
These nodes should have output data ports for the array element returned.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Put an Array variable or Array constant node on to the editor;
Pull the data port and select `Call`;
Select either `void front() const` or `void back() const`;

![screen shot 2017-10-04 at 12 46 53 am](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3048558/31142178-afb22c46-a8a3-11e7-8920-f0cdcb53e283.png)

![screen shot 2017-10-04 at 1 23 35 am](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3048558/31142191-b4b56c30-a8a3-11e7-9fb3-b74fd17bd86b.png)

data.title: Mono Glue Generation Fails
data.body:
**Operating system:** Arch Linux, Godot 3.0 custom build.
**Issue description:** Mono glue no longer being generated by --generate-mono-glue. The output that should appear when glue is generated is absent, and godot builds without the mono module. Found when testing after #11739. [`9b8376e`](https://github.com/BrainBlasted/Godot-Updater/commit/9b8376ef9276f3e27ddc3b0638baa9a08682b407) of my update script was working before. When trying manually, I produced [this](https://hastebin.com/raw/fagudemote) hastebin. Typing the commands to compile manually yielded no difference.
**Steps to reproduce:** Run godot --generate-mono-glue modules/mono/glue as detailed in the [GodotSharp building instructions](https://github.com/neikeq/GodotSharp/wiki/Building#generating-the-glue).

data.body:
be roughness == 1).

Also avoid calculating diffuse light calculation when metallic == 1.

data.title: Transform, Basis, Quat changes in Mono implementation

(Since GodotSharp has effectively been moved here, I'm moving [this issue](https://github.com/neikeq/GodotSharp/issues/49) here too.)

There's been compatibility breaking changes/fixed in these classes in Godot, so corresponding C# code will also need to be updated.

data.title: No sound in HTML5 WebAssembly export
data.body:
My config: Linux 64bits (Antergos distrib, Arch based, Godot compiled yesterday (3.0.r9756.66987d687-1), and the WebAssembly templates compiled on September the 19th.

I integrated a music to a test game, it works as expected launching from Godot and exported to Linux/X11 binary, but there is no sound in the WebAssembly export. I tried with the .ogg vorbis format and .wav format but no difference.

Here is the link to the exported project:
https://nylnook.art/godot-webassembly/turbo-argument.html
I can share the source files if needed.

And a test project, minimal example (with a sample from Minilens):
[test-sound.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/1352700/test-sound.zip)

Thanks for your work !

data.title: If a scene is open in godot and the scene file is modified outside godot a prompt should be given on whether or not to update or overwrite
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):**
Linux Mint.
Godot 2.1.4.
GPU irrelevant.

**Issue description:**
If a scene is open in Godot and the scene file is externally modified no prompt is given of this conflict, if changes are made in Godot, saving will overwrite the external modifications to the scene file.
It should prompt the user whether or not to update the scene according to the new scene file or whether to overwrite these.
Ideally it should prompt immediately as the external changes are made.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Create a scene, make a change and save.
With the scene still open in Godot then externally modify the scene file(i.e by git pulling a commit with modifications to the scene)

**Link to minimal example project:**
An example project with its own readme.
https://github.com/AlekhineDev/godot-bug-scene-conflict

data.title: doc_status.py: Add -t (--todo) option, show only non-empty items
data.body:
Currently, if you use `doc_statuc.py doc\classes -b` to see where work is needed, there are a lot of lines like this one below:

`VisualScriptSwitch | ... | 0/0 | 0/0 | 0/0 | 0/0 | 0%`

This adds a `-t` or `--todo` switch which filters these lines so that only those are shown where there are still items (methods, constants, members or signals) to document.

Meaning for at least one item, the value is neither 0/0 nor full, e.g. X/X. 

(Or rather, the value is X-n/X where X and n are both > 0, and n < X, I guess. :stuck_out_tongue:)
